prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Confirm the quiescent coronal emission of cool stars, as mentioned in Gudel (2002).For this purpose, we plan to observed the star HD 189733 at six different frequencies to obtain the spectra of its atmosphere.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: From a list of planet hosting stars, we selected the most promising one that is HD 189733. This is a young star of estimated age of 0.6 Gyr and is known to be magnetically active with spots on its surface (Pont et al. 2007). Besides observing at least 5 transits of this star at 345 GHz, we also like to have the spectra of the stellar atmosphere at six different frequencies during times when there is no transit. A conservative estimate of the flux at different frequencies were done considering the photospheric effective temperature of HD 189733, Teff=4980 K. However, the expected brightness temperature may be as large as a few million K. The integration time estimates were obtained assuming 2nd Octile and 7.5 GHz bandwidth. We propose to observe for 1 h at all 6 frequencies to investigate if there is any contribution from mechanisms other than bremsstrahlung. For gyromagnetic emission, the brightness temperature will be much larger than the effective temperature. Thus we propose to observe HD 189733 at 6 frequencies: 100, 200, 250, 300, 350, 650 for one hour each, to obtain the total flux density. The total time of this observation totaling 6 h.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Currently, over a thousand extrassolar planets have been detected, from these about 40% show planetary transits at visible wavelength. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the shape of a planetary transit at radio wavelengths. From simulations of transits using solar maps at 17 GHz from the Nobeyama interferometer, it was found that the shape of the transit differs from that in the visible in the sense that the brightened limb is seen. For the transits it was found that the best candidate was HD 189733, a young and active star. To better understant the atmosphere of the star, including its corona that has already been detected in X-rays, the goal is to observe the star at many frequencies to construct its spectra and determine the emission mechanism of this star.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radio Astronomy and Astrophysics, Mackenzie University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Campus Urbanova, Vale do Paraiba, University of
